node.title: Permissions issues - Cannot Run Input files create by ATOM
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I am a new user of MOOSE and have tried tutorial#01 and step #2. I have installed ATOM and created the input file and tried to run the file as shown below. However, it showed error message. It was fine when I run the existing file in the tutorial. The issue was shown whenever I recreate input files using ATOM. I don't know what causes the issue. I would really appreciate if you provide some inputs. Thanks. Sung
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler/problems$ ../babbler-opt -i pressure_diffusion.i
*** ERROR ***
Unable to open file "/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/problems/pressure_diffusion.i". Check to make sure that it exists and that you have read permission.
Stack frames: 10
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator >)
2: void mooseError<char const*>(char const*&&)
3: MooseUtils::checkFileReadable(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, bool, bool)
4: Parser::parse(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&)
5: MooseApp::setupOptions()
6: MooseApp::run()
7: ../babbler-opt(+0x41d1) [0x7f397a60c1d1]
8: __libc_start_main
9: ../babbler-opt(+0x44af) [0x7f397a60c4af]
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor

Hi Sung,
That is very odd, there should be no issue with atom.
Can you please run 'ls -l' in '~/projects/babbler/problems' so we can check the file permissions?
Best,
Guillaume

Thanks Guillaume. Please see below.
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler/problems$ ls -l
total 4
---------- 1 hyeom hyeom 1544 Nov 27 12:27 pressure_diffusion.i
In addition, when I typed "git status", it says "fatal: .git/index: index file open failed: Permission denied." I am not sure this is related to the input file issue.
Sincerely,
Sung

The --------- are the permissions for the file (for the owner, the group of users and all users). You currently do not have read (would show an r) or write permissions (would show a w).
Can you try changing the permissions of the file? On linux it's 'chmod +rw file_or_folder' to add read and write permissions. You can check the result with 'ls -l'. You may have to sudo for this command.
Is this run on a computing cluster? You may have to contact your platform administrator to resolve permissions issues.
Best,
Guillaume

Guillaume,
Thank you for the comment. I tried that and it shows as follows:
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:/projects/babbler/problems$ chmod +rw pressure_diffusion.i
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:/projects/babbler/problems$ ls -l
total 4
-rw-r--r-- 1 hyeom hyeom 1544 Nov 27 12:27 pressure_diffusion.i
Was it right command?
We have an workstation which group members share with through individual's college account. I am a first user to try to run MOOSE using the workstation.
Sincerely,
Sung
It looks right. Can you run the file now?

Guillaume,
Thanks. I am not sure there is another issue now. I just copy and paste the code in ATOM and saved as "pressure_diffusion.i" shown in the tutorial. Please see below. Sung
(moose) hyeom@ERB914-7920:~/projects/babbler/problems$ ../babbler-opt -i pressure_diffusion.i

*** ERROR ***
/home/hyeom/projects/babbler/problems/pressure_diffusion.i contains Windows(DOS) line endings which are not supported.

Stack frames: 10
0: libMesh::print_trace(std::ostream&)
1: moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >)
2: void mooseError<std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > >(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >&&)
3: MooseUtils::checkFileReadable(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, bool, bool)
4: Parser::parse(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)
5: MooseApp::setupOptions()
6: MooseApp::run()
7: ../babbler-opt(+0x41d1) [0x7f8fc56b01d1]
8: __libc_start_main
9: ../babbler-opt(+0x44af) [0x7f8fc56b04af]
application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor
run dos2unix pressure_diffusion.i if available

Dear dschwen,
I typed dos2unix pressure_diffusion.i in the prompt window. It said Command 'dos2unix' not found... I tried run dos2unix pressure_diffusion.i. It also said Command 'run' not found. I think I messed up something during installations of ATOM and Github. Sung

Hi Sung,
This is a common issue with Windows adding end-of-line characters to text files.
Please try the solutions listed here se_link as you don't have dos2unix installed on your system.
Guillaume

Thank you all.
I have installed "dos2unix" using the information shown in the link below (for future new users)
https://zoomadmin.com/HowToInstall/UbuntuPackage/dos2unix
I can run the input file after converting the file to unix format. Thanks. Sung
yep,i meet the same error. the dos2unix can fix the error, and i can also use vs code to change it(maybe this will be more convenient)

node.title: Can I define the solve order of the equations?
node.bodyText:
For example, if I want to firstly solve 3 equations(variables are v t and p) in block1 ang block2. When converged, solve the 4th equation(variable is w), put w into the frist 3 equations and solve the 3 equations again...until converged.
Like the SIMPLE algorithm, can I define this by myself? If I can, where should I write the code?
All I know about MOOSE now is that I write the equations into Kernel and MOOSE will solve the equations at the same time. But I think there must be a way to solve the equations in a user-defined order.

Hello
This would be a segregated solver and we do not currently support these. There's ongoing work on this.
For now you may use MultiApps to accomplish this
Guillaume
OK. This is helpful. Thank you!

node.title: ParaView software crashes when trying to open exodus files
node.bodyText:
So I'm trying to use ParaView to view exodus files created by diffusion models I'm running in MOOSE, but the software crashes as soon as I try to open them.
Here's the input file I'm using:
crash_input_example.txt
Meanwhile ParaView is able to easily display output files from input files such as this:
runs_fine_example.txt
If anyone has any ideas on why this might be happening it would be greatly appreciated. Thanks.

I had a very similar problem with the mesh generated by the FlowChannel1Phase components in the Thermal Hydraulics Module. In short, Paraview 5.10.1 didn't like 1D meshes from exodus files. 2D and 3D works fine, but 1D crashes Paraview 5.10.1. At the recommendation of a post somewhere on the internet I switched to Paraview 5.9.1 and everything worked as intended. I read that 5.10.1 has a legacy exodus reader that solves this problem, but rather than figuring out how to get that working I switched to 5.9.1.
Hopefully that's all that's wrong! Good luck!
EDIT: Apparently I read the solution here on this discussion board: #21138

You were right! ParaView 5.9.1 works perfectly for me. Thank you.
I raised the issue with 5.10.1 with ParaView's support team. Apparently it's an issue with the IOSSReader. I don't know much more than that but hopefully this is patched in 5.10 soon.

You can try to use the legacy exodus reader in paraview:
Tools > Manage Plugins > Legacy Exodus Reader > Select Plugin > reopen your file and select the appropriate reader.

node.title: Remeshing during simulation
node.bodyText: Sometime in the future, I want to implement a remesher for when the mesh gets deformed. For a first go around, I will use the built-in libMesh::LaplaceMeshSmoother. If someone could give an initial list of things I would need to think about that would be helpful. For example interpolate current material properties onto the new mesh, etc. Let me know if there are any examples in moose that would be helpful also. I will be diving deeper in this later in the future, but I wanted to get some feedback and hints in the meantime! Thanks for any help.

The list of things to consider:

projecting variables
projecting material properties
projecting stateful material properties
remeshing part of the domain, e.g. subdomain-restricted remeshing
iterative remeshing, e.g. your remeshing criteria may change after you remesh, so you may want to recompute the remeshing criteria which is possibly followed by another remeshing...
preserving locations of nodesets, sidesets, interfaces within a subdomain
optionally re-equilibriating the system after remeshing, which, again, may be followed by another remeshing in an iterative fashion.

For a prototype, I think 1 and 2 with a simple remeshing criteria is sufficient.
I wonder if the MOOSE team and/or Coreform already have projects along this line. You may want to check with them first.

Hello
So with the current capability there are essentially two ways I would do this:

write down all the mesh changing capability needed in a user object and execute this user object only when needed. You may use the Controls system to do that, to execute it exactly when you want to. This would be done in a single calculation/single input file approach.

OR

write all the necessary data (all field variables etc) to a restart file, either exodus or checkpoint. Then you will NOT be able to restart directly, but you may restart this data in a MultiApp executed on INITIAL with the original mesh then move the data over using transfers (which will take care of projections). This is a little obnoxious but our only work around for the element renumbering that would occur during remeshing

Note: If you are ONLY doing smoothing and the elements are the same, you may consider restarting directly
In the future (eg some time next FY) we will be able run mesh generators during a calculation.
Guillaume

node.title: userdefinedAction is trying to retrieve an optional parameter "lumping"

node.bodyText:
Hello
This is weird indeed, we should not be able to get to that error with lumping since it has a default.
In the backtrace it should say which kernel is getting to this error.
I think what you did in the action might have broken the parameters.
Do you need to do this ?
   params.applyParameters(parameters());

I've never used that to set parameters
Guillaume

must be coming from somewhere else then.
Let's double check, let's run this in a debugger and add a breakpoint on the abort and print the backtrace.
See those instructions
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/application_development/debugging.html

Here is all bt
(lldb) bt
* thread #1, queue = 'com.apple.main-thread', stop reason = breakpoint 1.1
* frame #0: 0x000000012c0c0f50 libmpi.12.dylibMPI_Abort frame #1: 0x0000000131ee9ebd libmoose-dbg.0.dylibmoose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(msg="Stack frames: 25\n0: 0   libmesh_dbg.0.dylib                 0x0000000140edf578 libMesh::print_trace(std::__1::basic_ostream<char, std::__1::char_traits >&) + 648\n1: 1   libmoose-dbg.0.dylib                0x0000000131ee9d1f moose::internal::mooseErrorRaw(std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits, std::__1::allocator >, std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits, std::__1::allocator >) + 879\n2: 2   libradtor_test-dbg.0.dylib          0x0000000108714908 void mooseError<char const (&) [16], std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits, std::__1::allocator > const&, char const (&) [40]>(char const (&) [16], std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits, std::__1::allocator > const&, char const (&) [40]) + 184\n3: 3   libradtor_test-dbg.0.dylib          0x0000000108714820 bool const& InputParameters::getParamHelper(std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits, std::__1::allocator > const&, InputParameters const"..., prefix="") at MooseError.C:83:3
frame #2: 0x0000000108714908 libradtor_test-dbg.0.dylibvoid mooseError<char const (&) [16], std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> > const&, char const (&) [40]>(args=<no value available>, args="lumping", args=<no value available>) [16], std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> > const&, char const (&) [40]) at MooseError.h:258:3 frame #3: 0x0000000108714820 libradtor_test-dbg.0.dylibbool const& InputParameters::getParamHelper(name="lumping", pars=0x000000014f092e88, (null)=0x0000000000000000) at InputParameters.h:1585:5
frame #4: 0x000000010993d8d5 libxfem-dbg.0.dylibbool const& MooseObject::getParam<bool>(this=0x000000015005ec18, name="lumping") const at MooseObject.h:266:10 frame #5: 0x0000000130538394 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibTimeDerivative::TimeDerivative(this=0x000000015005ec18, parameters=0x000000014f092e88) at TimeDerivative.C:32:38
frame #6: 0x00000001305385cd libmoose-dbg.0.dylibTimeDerivative::TimeDerivative(this=0x000000015005ec18, parameters=0x000000014f092e88) at TimeDerivative.C:33:1 frame #7: 0x00000001305e5c25 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibstd::__1::__shared_ptr_emplace<TimeDerivative, std::__1::allocator >::__shared_ptr_emplace<InputParameters const&>(this=0x000000015005ec00, __a=allocator @ 0x00000003040eb450, __args=0x000000014f092e88) at shared_ptr.h:295:37
frame #8: 0x00000001305e58fd libmoose-dbg.0.dylibstd::__1::__shared_ptr_emplace<TimeDerivative, std::__1::allocator<TimeDerivative> >::__shared_ptr_emplace<InputParameters const&>(this=0x000000015005ec00, __a=allocator<TimeDerivative> @ 0x00000003040eb488, __args=0x000000014f092e88) at shared_ptr.h:289:5 frame #9: 0x00000001305e57cf libmoose-dbg.0.dylibstd::__1::shared_ptr std::__1::allocate_shared<TimeDerivative, std::__1::allocator, InputParameters const&, void>(__a=0x00000003040eb560, __args=0x000000014f092e88) at shared_ptr.h:954:55
frame #10: 0x00000001305e56db libmoose-dbg.0.dylibstd::__1::shared_ptr<TimeDerivative> std::__1::make_shared<TimeDerivative, InputParameters const&, void>(__args=0x000000014f092e88) at shared_ptr.h:963:12 frame #11: 0x00000001305e5616 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibstd::__1::shared_ptr Registry::build<TimeDerivative, MooseObject>(parameters=0x000000014f092e88) at Registry.h:234:12
frame #12: 0x0000000131de56c7 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibFactory::create(this=0x000000015002c448, obj_name="TimeDerivative", name="C0_source", parameters=0x00000003040ec6d8, tid=0, print_deprecated=false) at Factory.C:125:14 frame #13: 0x00000001316d9360 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibstd::__1::shared_ptr Factory::create(this=0x000000015002c448, obj_name="TimeDerivative", name="C0_source", parameters=0x00000003040ec6d8, tid=0) at Factory.h:300:38
frame #14: 0x0000000131627fa4 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibNonlinearSystemBase::addKernel(this=0x000000015082e618, kernel_name="TimeDerivative", name="C0_source", parameters=0x00000003040ec6d8) at NonlinearSystemBase.C:446:18 frame #15: 0x0000000130d117e9 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibFEProblemBase::addKernel(this=0x000000014f838a18, kernel_name="TimeDerivative", name="C0_source", parameters=0x00000003040ec6d8) at FEProblemBase.C:2372:8
frame #16: 0x0000000112353f5d libphase_field-dbg.0.dylibRateTheoryKernelAction::act(this=0x000000014f7170e8) at RateTheoryKernelAction.C:55:15 frame #17: 0x0000000131413802 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibAction::timedAct(this=0x000000014f7170e8) at Action.C:91:3
frame #18: 0x000000013141316e libmoose-dbg.0.dylibActionWarehouse::executeActionsWithAction(this=0x000000015002c160, task="add_kernel") at ActionWarehouse.C:384:19 frame #19: 0x0000000131449ee9 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibActionWarehouse::executeAllActions(this=0x000000015002c160) at ActionWarehouse.C:344:5
frame #20: 0x0000000131e7204d libmoose-dbg.0.dylibMooseApp::runInputFile(this=0x000000015002ba18) at MooseApp.C:1040:21 frame #21: 0x0000000131e6bf21 libmoose-dbg.0.dylibMooseApp::run(this=0x000000015002ba18) at MooseApp.C:1400:5
frame #22: 0x0000000100014245 radtor-dbgmain(argc=3, argv=0x00000003040eda58) at main.C:33:8 frame #23: 0x000000020003b51e dyldstart + 462

My only clue at the moment is that maybe the action is called too early. I would register a task in the action which gets executed around the same time when other kernels are added.
Also can you try retrieving the lumping parameter from the param to check if it gives you the same error within the action before creating the kernel?

node.title: Issues installing Libmesh on cluster
node.bodyText:
Hi All,
I am installing Libmesh on a cluster with the following modules activated.
cmake/3.19.3-rhel8
Python/3.8.1
GCC/9.3.0
MPICH/3.2.1
OpenMPI/4.0.5-rhel8

I am able to install Petsc without any issues.
To install libmesh I am using the update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh script that comes with MOOSE.
I am able to configure libmesh, but the script fails when it tries to run make install
I receive the following error:
Making install in include
make[1]: Entering directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include'
Making install in libmesh
make[2]: Entering directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include/libmesh'
make  install-am
make[3]: Entering directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include/libmesh'
make[4]: Entering directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include/libmesh'
make[4]: Nothing to be done for 'install-exec-am'.
make[4]: Nothing to be done for 'install-data-am'.
make[4]: Leaving directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include/libmesh'
make[3]: Leaving directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include/libmesh'
make[2]: Leaving directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include/libmesh'
make[2]: Entering directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include'
make[3]: Entering directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include'
make[3]: Nothing to be done for 'install-exec-am'.
 /usr/bin/mkdir -p '/usr/local/include/libmesh'
/usr/bin/mkdir: cannot create directory ‘/usr/local/include/libmesh’: Permission denied
make[3]: *** [Makefile:1150: install-includeHEADERS] Error 1
make[3]: Leaving directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include'
make[2]: *** [Makefile:1344: install-am] Error 2
make[2]: Leaving directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include'
make[1]: *** [Makefile:1177: install-recursive] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory '/hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/raccoon/moose/libmesh/build/include'
make: *** [Makefile:32937: install-recursive] Error 1

Libmesh is trying to write in a directory that I do not have access to.
Is there any way to avoid this?
I have run this script successfully on this cluster before, so I am unsure of what has changed in how the script executes.
Thank you in advance!

Hello
So first you should only have one MPI library loaded
MPICH/3.2.1
OpenMPI/4.0.5-rhel8

are both MPIs
This is odd. What does env return? We're looking for an environment variable that is changing the install path
Guillaume

Ah good point
Here is the relevant section of env return
I still have an old Conda install, but it should be deactivated. I don't believe it would interfere with the script.
CONDA_EXE=/hpc/home/det12/mambaforge3/bin/conda
SSH_CONNECTION=10.237.17.196 36324 152.3.100.191 22
MODULES_RUN_QUARANTINE=LD_LIBRARY_PATH LD_PRELOAD
LANG=en_US.UTF-8
HISTCONTROL=ignoreboth

SSH_ASKPASS=/usr/libexec/openssh/gnome-ssh-askpass

_CE_CONDA=

Seems fine.
which mpi ended up being used? Try which mpicc to know

I cannot check that since I submitted this as a batch job. So I don't have access to that particular environment anymore.
I can rerun this which a single mpi module and let you know if that fixed anything.
Which module is the preferred one?

ok make sure to gather the environment then too
openmpi is slower but more reliable

I just submitted the job
Here is the environment it is working with
CONDA_SHLVL=1

It's picking up another PETSC than the one you installed:
PETSC_ARCH=arch-linux-c-opt
PETSC_DIR is set to /hpc/group/dolbowlab/det12/petsc
You ll need to set those two to your local PETSC before building libmesh
PETSC_ARCH=arch-moose
PETSC_DIR=/path/to/moose/petsc

Oh, I should have mentioned that. That is intentional. That version of petsc should work fine with MOOSE.
However, I have run this with the version of petsc in moose and with those environment variables and have run into the same issue that I posted originally. So I don't believe that would fix this particular issue.

The libmesh script just failed.
The same error occurs, even with having the single MPI module activated. So it was unrelated to that.
Does the script normally try to write to /usr/local/include or is that something going awry?

weirdly it seems like it?

By default, `make install' will install all the files in
`/usr/local/bin', `/usr/local/lib' etc.  You can specify
an installation prefix other than `/usr/local' using `--prefix',
for instance `--prefix=$HOME'.

can you try the prefix?

node.title: PorousFlow and Units
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I have a question regarding units in PorousFlow.
The unit system I usually use is mm, 1e3 kg, s, N, MPa.
Inside the FluidProperties-Module all units have to be SI, so m, kg, s, N, Pa. But PorousFlowSingleComponentFluid allows the user to set pressure_unit = MPa. Does that mean FluidProperties stays in SI and only the pressure parameters get multiplied by 10^6? Can I keep my normal unit system with mm and MPa or do I have to look out for anything else? For example is the unit for my permeability still mm^4 afterwards or do I have to change it?
This is explained fully at https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/PorousFlowSingleComponentFluid.html .   I'm glad you're using PorousFlow.   What are you modelling?

just a quick question @WilkAndy
if I use time_unit = years
does this mean my BC [PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink] flux_function is in m/years ?
Thanks!
Yep, that's correct @Traiwit

@WilkAndy I actually read that page and just wanted to make sure that I got it right, before making some silly mistakes. Did I get it right?
I'm modelling a porous cylinder that has a permeable top surface and gets pushed on by an indenter. So the goal is to restrict fluid outflow in the contact area and make fluid flow free in no-contact zones. It's running but it's a bit unstable sometimes.

You're probably doing the right thing, @Flolaffel .   Yes, permeability should be written in mm^2 units.  Remember your boundary tractions and pressures (for the indenter or confining pressures) must be specified in MPa.  Also, applying a force or pressure to an outer boundary is usually less stable than applying a displacement, which might be the reason for your occasional instability.  You could always trial standard units just to check you've done nothing wrong - the most painful aspect will probably be regenerating your mesh on the metre scale instead of mm.

Oh, i just noticed you wrote "mm^4" for permeability - not sure if that was a typo, but permeability should be in mm^2.  Also, Newtons = Pa.m^2 = MPa.mm^2, so if you're applying a force with the indenter you won't need to worry about its numerical value changing from standard SI units.

Thanks for your help.
My permeability unit wasn't a typo. I guess I just mixed some things up and ended up with a wrong unit.
I don't use any external Force BCs, I use the Contact Module to indent my cylinder. As a proof of concept you could say. I'm not exactly sure what about my simulation introduces the "disturbances" I'm getting but contact could be one of them. Still to be tested.

Oh yes, contact is a really difficult thing to simulate.  As an alternative, could you just apply a FunctionDirichletBC to control the displacement of a node or group of nodes, with the function approximating the indenter's movement?  At least that'd tell you whether the contact was the chief problem, or something wrong with your cylinder model.

Well I tried and: the convergence is problematic but the results seem as expected.
When using contact the convergence is fine actually but the results not so much. There are unexpected jumps in the porepressure. The cylinder is getting compressed all the time and still sometimes porepressure reduces and then jumps back up the next timestep. This doesn't happen with a displacement controlled simulation.
Do you have experience with combining PorousFlow and Contact in MOOSE? For example is there a way to make the indenter non-porous? Because right now he is porous with 0 permeability.

I haven't done anything like you're doing, sorry @Flolaffel .  Yes, you certainly can block-restrict PorousFlow, so its Variables live only on the cylinder, however that means you have to use the Kernels and Materials with block = cylinder because PorousFlow's Actions (eg PorousFlowFullySaturated don't have that functionality).  However, a cheap way of doing it is to set porosity = 0 and permeability = 0.  That way (unless you're using unusual Kernels) all the PorousFlow residuals will be zero on the indenter.  That means porepressure will remain fixed in the indenter.  (Porepressure is physically meaningless in the indenter, of course, but you'll still see it there in paraview and MOOSE.)   Currently, with permeability = 0 only, PorousFlow will keep the fluid mass fixed at each indenter node, which may actually be quite numerically difficult if you have realistic fluid properties, since porepressure could rise dramatically as the indenter squashes a bit.
Regarding convergence: have you read https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/convergence.html and https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/nonlinear_convergence_problems.html ?   I wonder whether you've tried SimpleFluidProperties because that almost always removes any problems related to fluid properties (eg, if you're inadvertently going through a phase transition).   I wonder whether you could share your mesh + input file, just for the "no-indenter" (DirichletBC) case?
To me, the porepressure jumping around sounds like the simulation hasn't converged properly, or fluid is flowing to/from the indenter or other boundaries?
a

Interesting...in my experience setting permeability = 0 converges while porosity = 0 completely destroys convergence. Something along the lines of failed factorization of Jacobian. How could that be? Maybe I'll have to resort to using all Kernels without any actions.
I haven't seen the pages you mentioned yet. But my PorousFlow part is single-phase, fully saturated, SimpleFluidProperties without any temperature or phase changes. And I'm using a PiecewiseLinearSink. The convergence criteria article is interesing, but I had to set mine very high in order to make the simulation go through. Maybe that is part of the problem. You'll see in my input, I have the absolute and relative criteria at 1e-3. But: the DirichletBC input I attached is the one where porepressure actually does what I expect it to, even with mentioned tolerances. In the contact input I had tolerances at 1e-7 and still got the weird behaviour. I don't know whether I can set them even lower than that and still expect convergence. Contact is not exactly easy to get to converge.
[Mesh]
  [cube]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 0.5
    nx = 30
    ny = 10
  []
  [sideset_left]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = cube
    bottom_left = '-0.1 0.4 0'
    top_right = '0.5 0.6 0'
    block_id = 0
    boundary_id_old = top
    boundary_id_new = 110
  []
  [sideset_right]
    type = SideSetsFromBoundingBoxGenerator
    input = sideset_left
    bottom_left = '0.5 0.4 0'
    top_right = '1.1 0.6 0'
    block_id = 0
    boundary_id_old = top
    boundary_id_new = 111
  []
  patch_update_strategy = auto
[]

[Problem]
  coord_type = RZ
[]

[GlobalParams]
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  gravity = '0 0 0'
  PorousFlowDictator = dictator
  volumetric_locking_correction = true
[]

[Variables]
  [porepressure]
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [tdisp_y]
    type = PiecewiseLinear
    x = '0  10   100'
    y = '0 -0.1 -0.1'
  []
[]

[Modules]
  [TensorMechanics/Master]
    [all]
      add_variables = true
      strain = FINITE
    []
  []
  [FluidProperties]
    [simple_fluid]
      type = SimpleFluidProperties
      bulk_modulus = 1e7 #Pa
      density0 = 1000 #rho in kg/m³
      thermal_expansion = 0
      viscosity = 1e-3 #mu in Pa*s
    []
  []
[]

[PorousFlowFullySaturated]
  coupling_type = HydroMechanical
  porepressure = porepressure
  biot_coefficient = 0.8
  displacements = 'disp_x disp_y'
  fp = simple_fluid
  stabilization = Full
  pressure_unit = MPa
[]

[BCs]
  [confinex]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_x
    value = 0
    boundary = 'left bottom'
  []
  [confiney]
    type = DirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    value = 0
    boundary = 'bottom'
  []
  [topload]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = disp_y
    function = tdisp_y
    boundary = 110
  []    
  [outflow]
    type = PorousFlowPiecewiseLinearSink
    variable = porepressure
    boundary = 111
    pt_vals = '-1e9 1e9'
    multipliers = '-1e9 1e9'
    PT_shift = 0
    flux_function = 10
    fluid_phase = 0
    use_mobility = true
    use_relperm = true
  []
[]

[Materials]
  [elasticity_cube]
    type = ComputeIsotropicElasticityTensor
    shear_modulus = 0.5
    bulk_modulus = 320
  []
  [stress]
    type = ComputeFiniteStrainElasticStress
  []
  [porosity_cube]
    type = PorousFlowPorosity
    fluid = true
    mechanical = true
    porosity_zero = 0.5 
    biot_coefficient = 0.8 
    solid_bulk = 320
  []
  [permeability_cube]
    type = PorousFlowPermeabilityConst
    permeability = '0.25e-9 0 0   0 0.25e-9 0   0 0 0.25e-9'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [andy]
    type = SMP
    full = true
    petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_factor_mat_solver_package'
    petsc_options_value = 'lu       mumps'
    
    #petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -pc_hypre_type'
    #petsc_options_value = 'hypre boomeramg'
    
    #petsc_options_iname = '-ksp_type -pc_type -sub_pc_type -sub_pc_factor_shift_type -pc_asm_overlap'
    #petsc_options_value = 'gmres      asm      lu           NONZERO                   2             '
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  solve_type = Newton
  start_time = 0
  end_time = 10
  dt = 0.5  
  nl_max_its = 100
  nl_abs_tol = 1e-3
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-3
[]

[Outputs]
  csv = true
  exodus = true
[]

Last but not least: Fluid should not be able to reach the indenter since it has no permeability and I restrict the outflow where contact is happening with a Sink (the process of restricting outflow on the left half of the top boundary while using contact differs from the input I attached here). Maybe there is a problem with the sink in the contact simulation. But the effect only happens with "high" bulk moduli for the porous media. Using up to a few MPa is no Problem but at around 10 MPa it starts acting weird. You can see I used over 300 MPa with the Dirichlet-Input and it worked fine.

node.title: Export displacements as a vector variable.
node.bodyText: Hi, I'm trying to use VTK or Tecplot outputs to get around Exodus's inability to have elements of disparate types in the same block, however, when viewing a VTK or tecplot file, Paraview does not automatically detect and combine the three displacment variables into a vector to all the mesh to be displaced/deformed. I have attempted to solve this by making a LAGRANGE_VEC aux variable, but have been unable to find the correct aux kernel for combining a number of LAGRANGE variables into a LAGRANGE_VEC. BuildArrayVariableAux does not allow for the use of vectors, and if I use an array instead then the same issue persists where paraview reads the components as three separate variables instead of a vector.

BuildArrayVariableAux is for array variables not vector variables.
You may just name your variables
var_x
var_y
var_z
to get Paraview to recognize them as vectors.
You could also add a BuildVectorVariableAux to the framework, we'd be happy to have this
Guillaume

node.title: RuntimeError: Multi-download failed when install moose-tools
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I am trying to install moose on a machine with Ubuntu 18.04.5 LTS following the instructions on
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/installation/conda.html
However, when I move to  mamba install moose-tools moose-libmesh
the error occurs as follows:
> # >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> ERROR REPORT <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<
> 
>     Traceback (most recent call last):
>       File "/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/conda/exceptions.py", line 1082, in __call__
>         return func(*args, **kwargs)
>       File "/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mamba/mamba.py", line 951, in exception_converter
>         raise e
>       File "/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mamba/mamba.py", line 945, in exception_converter
>         exit_code = _wrapped_main(*args, **kwargs)
>       File "/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mamba/mamba.py", line 901, in _wrapped_main
>         result = do_call(args, p)
>       File "/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mamba/mamba.py", line 763, in do_call
>         exit_code = install(args, parser, "install")
>       File "/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mamba/mamba.py", line 507, in install
>         index = load_channels(pool, channels, repos)
>       File "/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mamba/utils.py", line 122, in load_channels
>         index = get_index(
>       File "/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/lib/python3.9/site-packages/mamba/utils.py", line 103, in get_index
>         is_downloaded = dlist.download(api.MAMBA_DOWNLOAD_FAILFAST)
>     **RuntimeError: Multi-download failed.**
> 
> `$ /home/hdj2/mambaforge3/bin/mamba install moose-tools moose-libmesh`
> 
>   environment variables:
>                  CIO_TEST=<not set>
>         CONDA_DEFAULT_ENV=moose
>                 CONDA_EXE=/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/bin/conda
>              CONDA_PREFIX=/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/envs/moose
>     CONDA_PROMPT_MODIFIER=(moose)
>          CONDA_PYTHON_EXE=/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/bin/python

>            CURL_CA_BUNDLE=<not set>
>                      PATH=/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/bin:/home/hdj2/mambaforge3/envs/moose/bin:/home
>                           /hdj2/mambaforge3/condabin:/home/hdj2/.local/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/
>                           local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin:/usr/games:/usr/local/games:/s
>                           nap/bin
>        REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE=<not set>
>             SSL_CERT_FILE=<not set>
>                WINDOWPATH=2
> 
>      active environment : moose
>     active env location : /home/hdj2/mambaforge3/envs/moose
>             shell level : 1
>        user config file : /home/hdj2/.condarc
>  populated config files : /home/hdj2/mambaforge3/.condarc
>                           /home/hdj2/.condarc
>           conda version : 4.12.0
>     conda-build version : not installed
>          python version : 3.9.13.final.0
>        virtual packages : __linux=5.4.0=0
>                           __glibc=2.27=0
>                           __unix=0=0
>                           __archspec=1=x86_64
>        base environment : /home/hdj2/mambaforge3  (writable)
>       conda av data dir : /home/hdj2/mambaforge3/etc/conda
>   conda av metadata url : None
>            channel URLs : https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/linux-64
>                           https://conda.software.inl.gov/public/noarch
>                           https://conda.anaconda.org/idaholab/linux-64
>                           https://conda.anaconda.org/idaholab/noarch

>           package cache : /home/hdj2/mambaforge3/pkgs

>        envs directories : /home/hdj2/mambaforge3/envs
>                           /home/hdj2/.conda/envs
>                platform : linux-64
>              user-agent : conda/4.12.0 requests/2.27.1 CPython/3.9.13 Linux/5.4.0-72-generic ubuntu/18.04.5 glibc/2.27
>                 UID:GID : 1000:1000
>              netrc file : None
> idaholab/linux-64                                    3.0kB @   6.6kB/s 404 failed  0.5s
> idaholab/noarch                                      3.0kB @   6.6kB/s 404 failed  0.5s

Then I searched for this in our forum and find sth similar as in this link: #20437
But things are different when I input  conda config --show channels
it occurs like:
(moose) hdj2@hdj2-Precision-T3610:~$ conda config --show channels
channels:
  - https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
  - idaholab
  - conda-forge
  - defaults

I also found this discussion from mamba forum  mamba-org/mamba#496
maybe it is something about mamba and curl,  but I still did not get the point on how to solve this.
Could you please help have a look at this installation problem?
Thank you very much in advance!
Best regards,
Daijun

Hello
please remove the idaholab channel then try again. It s deprecated
guillaume

Hi guillaume
Thank you! It works fine now.
Best regards,
Daijun

node.title: Summer 2022 MOOSE Workshop
node.bodyText:
Idaho National Laboratory (INL) will be hosting a MOOSE workshop June 6th and 7th, 2022. Attendance to the workshop is free of charge, but you must register by filling out the Google form (https://bit.ly/3rVLuNL).
The workshop will run from 8:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m MT on Mon. and Tues. We will be hosting guest speakers for lunch time talks. After registering you can expect to receive additional details regarding the workshop via email as the dates approach. For more information about MOOSE see mooseframework.inl.gov and if you have questions, please contact @permcody at cody.permann@inl.gov.
This training covers the basic operation of MOOSE, focusing on the development of a multi-physics MOOSE-based application. The training aims to provide the basics of MOOSE such that attendees will have the necessary skills to begin developing a MOOSE-based application to meet their own needs.
In Person Attendance will be capped and INL Requires ~30 days to clear international staff members who would like to attend. Please register at your earliest convenience.
NOTE: We do not automatically send a confirmation of your registration but rest assured we've got it. We'll contact you with more details as the workshop approaches.
Once again, the registration form can be found at: https://bit.ly/3rVLuNL
Is there an estimate on when we can watch the recording from the training last week?
can we watch the recording?
